title: After big drop in ISP competition, Canada mandates fiber-network sharing
description: Would be funny if Canada responded to Bell by threatening to nationalize them.

title: An inspirational story: tenacity
description: In this life, you don't have to prove nothin' to nobody but yourself.

title: Android 14’s storage disaster gets patched, but your data might be gone
description: It's the start of November, and that means a new Android security patch. Google claims this one is fixing a high-profile Android 14 storage bug that was locking some people out of their devices.

title: Apple Delays Work on Next Year’s iPhone, Mac Software to Fix Bugs
description: In a rare move, Apple Inc. hit pause on development of next year’s software updates for the iPhone, iPad, Mac and other devices so that it could root out glitches in the code.

title: Banning End-to-End Encryption is Stupid
description: I'm not sure if writing code on GitHub to be run in a terminal is going to change policy makers' minds.

title: Chamberlain blocks smart garage door opener from working with smart homes
description: I felt a great disturbance in IoT, as if millions of garage doors suddenly cried out in terror and were suddenly silenced.

title: EU's concealment of secret 'expert list' on CSAM regulation is maladministration
description: The next time there are elections for the Commission I will ... hey, wait a minute!

title: Firefox will support at least 200 new extensions on Android this December
description: If Firefox is your desktop browser of choice, you might have several extensions installed to avoid some common annoyances. Ads and cookie consent forms, for example, can be limited and managed through the use of Firefox extensions. However, Mozilla has featured limited support for these tools in the mobile version of the browser. Now, Firefox 120 is expected to launch in a much different direction.

title: Go, Containers, and the Linux Scheduler
description: Or you could use CPU reservations instead of limits.

title: Google turns to regulators to make Apple open up iMessage
description: My Trillian IM hasn't been able to access Google Chat for about two years now. How about opening up your messaging APIs, eh Google?

title: Google’s “Web Integrity” Android API could kill “alternative” media clients
description: Google is killing off its proposal for "Web Environment Integrity API" as a new web standard, though Android phones may still have to deal with it. According to Google's proposal document, the primary goal of the project was to "allow web servers to evaluate the authenticity of the device and honest representation of the software stack"—basically Google wanted a DRM gatekeeper for the web. The project got widespread coverage in July and was widely panned.

title: Microsoft won’t let you close OneDrive on Windows until you explain yourself
description: Needs an option that says, "Because it's my computer."

title: NewPipe - The lightweight YouTube experience for Android
description:
NewPipe has been created with the purpose of getting the original YouTube experience on your smartphone without annoying ads and questionable permissions.

The application is open source and you can check on it at GitHub.

title: Samsung expects the Galaxy S24 to sell like hotcakes thanks to AI
description: AI is the hottest buzzword in the tech industry right now. It holds the potential to fundamentally change how we use many of our devices and services daily. Unsurprisingly, many Android manufacturers are in a race to integrate AI-powered features into their phones to entice more customers.

title: Scientists Are Researching a Device That Can Induce Lucid Dreams on Demand
description: Ever heard of Rekall? They sell those fake memories. A friend of mine tried one their "special offers," nearly got himself lobotomized.

title: Verizon, AT&T Customers Sue To Reverse T-Mobile Merger, Saying It Raised Everybody’s Prices
description: We just got done noting how pretty much all of the criticism of the Sprint T-Mobile merger by economists and consumer advocates wound up being true. The deal has resulted in more than 10,000+ eliminated jobs, steady price hikes, annoying new fees, a weaker T-Mobile brand, and a lower quality product overall.
